title: Qantas first-quarter revenue hits record $4.5b
text:
Qantas has flagged a $25 million hit to its first-half profit due to the ongoing unrest in Hong Kong, and said deteriorating trade conditions will take its toll on the airline in the full-year result.

But the company was able to defy these pressures, as well as falling revenue in its domestic business, to boost its overall revenue 1.8 per cent in the three months ended September 30 to a record $4.56 billion from $4.49 billion in the year-earlier period.

"Qantas International has seen significant upside from competitor capacity contracting more than anticipated, which is expected to continue for at least the remainder of the first half," Qantas chief Alan Joyce said. Supplied

Qantas's international unit was responsible for most of the growth, with revenue in that division increasing 4.4 per cent.

"Protests in Hong Kong will negatively impact the group's first-half profit performance by $25 million with ongoing capacity reduction in place to minimise the second-half impact," the country's biggest airline said in a statement to the stock exchange.

"Further deterioration in global trade conditions has impacted freight demand with an expected profit impact of $25 million - $30 million for the full year," the statement said.
description: Qantas starts the new financial year with a bump in revenue, but it has also flagged a hit to future profit because of Hong Kong protests and less freight traffic.
